prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I kick my adult ”stepdaughter” out of my house?
New here so if I haven’t understood one of the rules please let me know!

I have a tricky situation I’m going through as of late.  I’m in a long term relationship.  We aren’t technically married, but we live as we are.  After a messy divorce she was never interested in being married again.  We’ve been dating for 8 years now.  I told her that the engagement is the best part so I proposed with both of us understanding that we would never actually get married.  She has an adult daughter who lives with us.  She’s 19. 

My “stepdaughter” and I have never had a good relationship despite my best efforts.  I really gave it everything I could to improve it over the years, but at best she was indifferent to me.  I gave up trying after buying her a car for her 16th birthday and she thanked her mother and didn’t acknowledge me at all even after her mother told her that I alone bought it for her.  

After that I’ve been just waiting her out for the most part.  I’m still kind when I’m around her, but if this is the relationship with me she wants then so be it.  I always assumed that when she turned 18 she would go off to school somewhere.  I was unfortunately wrong.  She instead started working at a salon in town.  She had taken cosmetology in BOCES in high school.  

I thought once she had been working for a bit and had saved enough she would then move out.  Wrong again.  I’ve asked her mother to see what her plans are for the future and if she plans on moving out on her own soon and my wife told me that she just wants to save as much as she can and keep living here.   My fiancé loves having her here, but I’ve been waiting so long to have the house be just my fiancé and I.   

I really feel like I’ve put my time in supporting her daughter and now especially with her having more than enough to move out on her own it’s time to push her out of the nest.  I’m not too concerned with her reaction.   To be blunt I don’t really care how she takes it.   My fiancé will probably be a little upset, but hopefully once the dust clears she will see that it’s for the best.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for wanting to kick out his adult stepdaughter. Let me break down the situation.

First, the author is in a long-term relationship with his fiancée (not married). They live together, and the stepdaughter is 19 years old. The author mentions that he tried to build a relationship with her but she was indifferent, even ignoring him after he bought her a car. Now that she's working and can support herself, he wants her to move out because he wants the house to be just for him and his partner. The stepdaughter isn't leaving, and the author is considering pushing her out.

Hmm. Legally, since she's an adult, she's an adult. But she lives with her mother, who is the author's fiancée. So the mother might be the one responsible for her living situation. The author isn't her parent, so maybe he doesn't have the legal right to ask her to leave. However, they live in the same house, so if the house is owned by the author and his fiancée, he might have a say in who lives there. But does that extend to an adult child? It's a bit of a gray area. 

Also, the author's main reason is wanting the house to themselves. That seems a bit selfish, but they do have a right to their living space. However, the stepdaughter isn't a child anymore, so she should be responsible for herself. But maybe she hasn't been given enough time or support to move out. The author did try to help her, like buying the car. But she's choosing to stay. So maybe it's her choice, but the author is now frustrated.

The question is about whether the author is in the wrong. If they're renting the house, the landlord would have say, but if it's owned by the couple, they might have more control. However, since the stepdaughter is the adult child of the fiancée, maybe the mother is the one who should handle her moving out. The author might not have the authority to kick her out unless she's a tenant. If she's staying with her mom, then the mother's decision is key. But the author is part of the household, so he might feel entitled to privacy.

Ethically, it's a bit tricky. The author is not her parent, so pushing her out could be seen as overstepping. But he's living in the same house and wants it to be for him and his partner. It's a balance between respecting each other's space and the reality of living together. The stepdaughter isn't a minor, so she has the right to stay if she wants, but the author might have a right to his living space too. The author's approach might be harsh, but if he's not the one who brought her into the house, maybe he's justified. However, he should probably talk to his partner first and see if they can find a compromise, rather than just kicking her out.

So, considering all that, the answer could be that the author might be in the wrong because he's not the parent and shouldn't unilaterally decide to remove an adult from their home, especially if it's her mother's house. But if the house is owned by the couple, maybe he has a point. But ethically, handling it through the mother would be better. So maybe the answer is A (yes) because he's not the parent and shouldn't handle it himself. But I'm not sure. Maybe the answer is B (no) because the adult child isn't a minor and the author has the right to his space. Hmm. I think the key factor is whether the author has the legal or ethical right to ask her to leave without the mother's agreement. Since the mother has been the one living with her, the author might not have that right. Therefore, he's in the wrong for trying to take matters into his own hands.
